content: Hi everyone, I am using Thunderbird 115 with the IMAP protocol to receive emails. I found that my Thunderbird profile folder is very large at 565GB, but my email occupies only 40GB on the server. I checked the contents of my configuration folder and found many files named nstmp-1 nstmp-2 etc, dozens of them, which are taking up a lot of my hard disk space. I want to know what these nstmp files are for, can I delete them, and what impact will deleting them have on my emails? Thank you all.
creator: hsy906

content: Did you check "Enable Global Search and Indexer" in Settings > General > Network & Disk Space > Indexing?
creator: Mapenzi

content: Thanks - yes, those are enabled. It may have been an issue with the folder indexing, because I rebuilt the index (again) and that solved the problem, the conversation view is active again.
creator: kolorado

content: Actually, I should have checked the issue more thoroughly before replying. The conversation view is available again for my IMAP folders, but still not for my LOCAL folders, even though the index was rebuilt for the local folders as well and the search now seem to work fine on those. I do not understand how the ability of showing the conversation view is affected, but it is still clearly missing for the local folders.
creator: kolorado

content: There is folder indexing via R-click > Properties > Repair folder. This action creates a new "folder.msf" index file in the profile; e.g. "Inbox.msf" The "Global Search" index file is named global-messages-db.sqlite, it is sstored in the profile folder. It can be useful to "renew" it from time to time: TB closed, delete this file and restart TB. Wait until the index has been rebuilt; you can follow the progression in the "Activity" window
creator: Mapenzi

content: When it is enabled the global search indexes all messages in IMAP and POP accounts as well as all messages stored in the Local Folders. One exception: by default messages in "Trash" folders are excluded from indexing.
creator: Mapenzi

content:
This is what I started with when I first encountered issues with the global search (i.e. deleting the global database from the profile folder). But it didn't solve the problem and created this new one. Now there is yet another issue, which is that compacting the folders do not work, as TB complains "The folder '%S' could not be compacted because writing to folder failed. Verify that you have enough disk space, and that you have write privileges to the file system, then try again." - while I haven't changed the location of the folder, and there's plenty of place on the drive, so this seems to be something else.

I would be willing to start fresh with a new profile, but I'm not sure what I should transfer from my existing profile. I don't want to loose any email and also settings would be nice to keep. I have to note that some of my local folders contain lots of emails and therefore are big (~6Gb). But I assume that TB can deal with this and this is not supposed to affect the behaviour of the program.
creator: kolorado

content:
You will only get a bounce back email from server under specific conditions.

1. Mailbox does not exist - maybe email address not correctly typed or email address no longer exists as user stopped account.

2. Mailbox is full - the owner of email address has used up all their server quota so server cannot receive any emails until some get deleted to create space.

3. Cannot be sent - maybe you have exceeded a sending limit or server needs authentication from sender or server is temporarilly down etc.

4. Refused by server due to Server Spam filters rejecting either content of email or IP address or email address.

But if you just sent an email intended for person A, but you accidentally sent it to person B then there's nothing wrong with email and it got delivered. Person B may have ignored it or realised it's not for them and deleted it. Or they may not have even looked at their emails, so do not know they have received it. But there is no reason for a server to bounce it back. The email address was ok and the server mailbox received it.

There is no way Thunderbird nor any server can know who you want to send to, only you know what email address should be entered. So basically, you just sent a perfectly good email but not necessarilly to the correct person.

Correct. It should work ok.

2. If I do this, I will not be able to transfer my profile back to Fedora when I get it working again (because the version number there is lower) ?

Correct if profile is left as is. But, if you Exit Thunderbird and access profile name folder, then delete the 'compatibility.ini' file, you should be able to use the profile on an older version.

content:
Is the account an IMAP account ? If yes, then it's possible that your server Spam folder may have emails put into it by the server and also by Thunderbird.

In the Junk/Spam folder Enable the 'Spam' column header if not already enabled. If greyed out flame icon then email put there by server. If red flame icon then Thunderbird put it in Junk. Q: What colour are the flame icons ?

re :Turned off SpamAssasin. Do you mean - in Account Settings > Junk Settings, you unchecked the option 'Trust junk mail headers set by 'SpamAssassin' ? Q: Is that option still checked or not ?

Q: Have you downloaded/installed SpamAssassin? If yes, have you 'turned it off' ?

content:
There are a few fee-based email trackers available, usually on a monthly or annual pay basis, but this article summarizes the futility of the effort (for example, read receipts aren't even available when writing to Gmail users): 

https://www.techadvisor.com/article/735201/how-to-tell-if-someone-has-read-your-email-or-not.html   An email tracking service is software that follows the email to the destination, whereas email clients (such as Thunderbird) send the message into the internet for delivery, relying on the SMTP server to do its work.
creator: davidsk

creator: Mapenzi

content:
Here are a few various options depending upon what you are trying to achieve.

If you know the name of folder and want to see all emails in that folder: via 'Menu Bar' Toolbar

  • Edit > Find > Search Messages
  • Search for messages in: choose folder name on the account.
  • 'To' 'begins with' and type first part of your email address
  • click on search

It should show all contents of the desired folder.

If you want to locate all folders that only contain eg: 'unread' mail:

  • In 'Folder Pane Header'
  • click on the far right 3 dot icon > Folder Modes > select 'Unread Folders'

They will show as a block of folders in Folder Pane. They may get added to the bottom of the Folder Pane, but you can move it to the top

  • Locate 'Unread Folders' block and click on 3 dot icon and select 'Move up'

If you frequently use or are currently wanting to work on a small group of folders, you can set them up as 'Favourite Folders' : Right click on folder and select 'Favourite folder'

  • In 'Folder Pane Header'
  • click on the far right 3 dot icon > Folder Modes > select 'Favourite Folders'

This saves you from having to keep scrolling to locate them.


There is also an addon which may work for you - please note addon extensions are maintained by the author and not Thunderbird.

  • https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-GB/thunderbird/addon/quick-folder-key-navigation/

How to install an addon:

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/installing-addon-thunderbird

content:
re:"A newer version of Thunderbird may have made changes to your profile which are no longer compatible with this older version.

That means you were previously using a newer version than the one you have currently got installed.

Try this:

I'm assuming you are using a Windows OS and have used a Thunderbird installation from this link so profile is in the default location. https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

  1. Exit Thunderbird
  2. In windows search bottom left of screen type: %Appdata% - see image as guide
  3. Select the %Appdata% file folder option
  4. Select 'Roaming'
  5. Select 'Thunderbird'
  6. Select the original profile name
  7. Look for this file and delete it : 'compatibility.ini'
  8. Start Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: click view>folders and tick 'folder pane headers' if menu bar is not visible, press alt key first
creator: davidsk

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next
